intro: Sambucus intermedia f. neomexicana, commonly known as the New Mexico elderberry, is a shrub native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the Caprifoliaceae family and is characterized by its compound leaves and clusters of small, white flowers. The plant produces dark purple berries that are edible and often used in culinary and medicinal applications. It thrives in well-drained soils and is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments. Its botanical features make it an important plant in both ecological and horticultural contexts.
